name: Haarlem
fun_fact: Fun fact: Haarlem is the birthplace of Frans Hals and the Dutch Golden Age of painting, but it's also home to Jopenkerk - a stunning church converted into a brewery where you drink craft beer beneath Gothic arches and stained glass windows!

hero_dishes.name: Haarlems Joppiesaus
hero_dishes.description: A creamy curry-onion sauce that originated in Haarlem, now found throughout the Netherlands
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in the 1980s at snackbar De Jopie - the sauce became so popular it spread nationwide and is now an essential accompaniment to fries
hero_dishes.where_to_find: De Jopie snackbar (original), frites shops throughout Haarlem

hero_dishes.name: Haarlemse Halve Maantjes
hero_dishes.description: Half-moon shaped chocolates, Haarlem's signature sweet
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by local chocolatiers, these crescents reference the city's coat of arms. Various fillings from cream to praline
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Boutique chocolatiers in the centrum, Chocolate Company

hero_dishes.name: Kibbeling
hero_dishes.description: Battered and fried chunks of fish, served with garlic sauce or mayo
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Dutch street food - originally made from the cheeks of cod. Now often whiting or other white fish
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Fish stalls at Grote Markt, Albert Cuyp Market when in Amsterdam

hero_dishes.name: Stamppot
hero_dishes.description: Mashed potatoes mixed with vegetables - boerenkool (kale) or hutspot (carrot and onion)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Dutch comfort food, especially popular in winter. Served with rookworst (smoked sausage)

signature_drinks.name: Jopen Beer
signature_drinks.description: Craft beers brewed in a 14th-century church, recreating medieval Haarlem brewing traditions
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At Jopenkerk brewery - drink beneath Gothic arches. Try Koyt (medieval grain beer) or Hoppenbier

signature_drinks.name: Genever
signature_drinks.description: Dutch gin, the predecessor of English gin
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Neat in a tulip glass, often with beer ('kopstoot' - headbutt)

food_culture_notes: Grote Markt has excellent food stalls and outdoor terraces surrounding St. Bavo Church
Jopenkerk brewery recreates beer recipes from when Haarlem was a major brewing center (1500s)
Just 15 minutes from Amsterdam - the food scene is excellent without tourist crowds
Brown cafÃ©s (bruine kroegen) are traditional Dutch pubs with dark wood interiors
